questions.question: Core loop in Lean Startup:
questions.additionalContext: Build experiments, measure results, and learn to refine the next iteration.

questions.question: MVP stands for:
questions.additionalContext: MVP validates riskiest assumptions quickly with minimal investment.

questions.question: Primary goal of MVP:
questions.additionalContext: Focus on learning, not completeness; ship the smallest experiment that yields signal.

questions.question: Actionable metrics are:
questions.additionalContext: They map directly to decisions (e.g., pricing change) and can be repeated.

questions.question: Pivot means:
questions.additionalContext: A pivot changes strategy while preserving the vision, based on validated learning.

questions.question: Cohort analysis helps with:
questions.additionalContext: Tracks behavior by user cohorts to see retention and engagement patterns.

questions.question: Riskiest assumption first principle:
questions.additionalContext: Test the assumption that would most undermine the idea if false.

questions.question: Good MVP characteristic:
questions.additionalContext: An MVP is quick to build and instrumented to measure outcomes.

questions.question: Describe one experiment you would run to validate a pricing hypothesis and your success metric.
questions.sampleStrongResponse: A/B test two price points on a landing page; measure conversion to signup and downstream retention at 2 weeks.

questions.question: Explain how you would decide to pivot vs persevere after two MVP iterations.
questions.sampleStrongResponse: Compare actionable metrics to thresholds; if north‑star metric is below target with negative trend and qualitative feedback indicates mismatch, pivot with a new hypothesis.
